metadata.title: A vector-based vaccine dose after three doses of mRNA-based COVID-19 vaccination does not substantially improve humoral SARS-CoV-2 immunity in renal transplant recipient

body_text.text: The SARS-COV-2 reactive antibody titers detected after the fourth vaccination of KTX with Ad26.COV2.S were correlated with the frequencies of (A) CD4 + CD137 + CD69 + , (B) CD4 + CD137 + IFN-γ + , (C) CD4 + CD137 + IL-2 + , (D) CD4 + CD137 + TNF-α + T cells. The serum neutralization capacity was also correlated with the frequencies of (E) CD4 + CD137 + CD69 + , (F) CD4 + CD137 + IFN-γ + , (G) CD4 + CD137 + IL-2 + , (H) CD4 + CD137 + TNF-α + T cells. Data of n=20 KTX that were vaccinated with Ad26.COV2.S after three BNT162b2 failed to induce substantial humoral responses.

Due to the high risk of a severe of a COVID-19 course, we offered a booster vaccine dose with Ad26.COV2.S (Johnson & Johnson) to all renal transplant recipients with humoral nonresponse after three COVID-19 vaccine doses at the Transplant Center of Ruhr-University Bochum. All patients gave written informed consent for the off-label use of this 4 th dose. The ethical committee of the Ruhr University of Bochum approved the Immunomonitoring of vaccine responses (Reg.-Nr. 20-7126). Patients who met the following criteria were included: a) Patients that received their 3rd vaccine dose four weeks prior the assessment of serological responsethe vaccination b) low or no antibodies binding to SARS-CoV-2 S protein should be detected by ELISA measured using Elecsys Anti-SARS-CoV-2 S and detection level of <0.80 U/ml were included in the study.

Blood samples of 20 kidney transplant recipients with no or low level of SARS-CoV-2-specific antibody after three doses of mRNA-based vaccination were collected after the written informed consent was obtained. The fourth booster vaccination was Ad26.COV2.S (Johnson & Johnson, New Brunswick, New Jersey, USA) and injected > 28 days after the third vaccination. Blood samples were obtained right before the administrations of Ad26.COV2.S, and 27 to 43 days after the Ad26.COV2.S vaccination. No adjustment of immunosuppression was performed within vaccination procedure.

Serum was obtained from blood collected into S-Monovette Z-Gel (Sarstedt) according to the manufacturer's instructions. For the determination of IgG to SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, the Elecsys® Anti-SARS-CoV-2 S (Roche Diagnostics International Ltd, Rotkreuz, Switzerland) immunoassay was used. The assay has a linear detection range up to 250 IU/ml.

To analyze virus neutralization assay in KTx with SARS-COV-2 reactive IgGs, a propagationincompetent VSV*G(FLuc) pseudovirus system bearing the SARS-CoV-2 S (D614G) protein or the SARS-CoV-2 B.1.617.2 (Delta) (EPI_ISL_1921353) S-protein the envelope was incubated with serial dilutions of immune sera prior to infections of Vero E6 cells as previously described (Zettl et al.) . Firefly luciferase (FLuc) activity was determined 18 hours post infection, and the reciprocal antibody dilution causing 50% inhibition of the luciferase reporter was calculated (PVN50).
body_text.section: SARS-CoV-2 WT and Delta-VOC neutralization assay

body_text.text: SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein reactive T cells were quantified by flow cytometry as previously described (Thieme et al., 2020) . In brief, peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) were isolated from peripheral blood by Ficoll-Hypaque density gradient centrifugation. Isolated PBMC were stimulated with 15mer overlapping peptides pools (OPP) with an 11 amino acids overlaps from SARS-CoV-2 wild type S-protein (JPT, Germany). For the analysis of Delta-VOCreactive T cell response, a pool of 32 15-mer peptides (Miltenyi Biotec, Germany) covering all 10 mutations of the Delta-VOC or the corresponding positions in the Wuhan variant (Miltenyi Biotec) were used. All OPP were dissolved according to the manufacturer's instructions and used at a final concentration of 1 μg/ml. Untreated PBMC were used as negative control to assess unspecific background activation. As a positive control, PBMC were stimulated with SEB (1 μg/ml, Sigma Aldrich). After 2h of stimulation, Brefeldin-A (Sigma-Aldrich) was added and cells were harvested after 16h. Surface-and intracellular-staining for flow cytometry was performed using fixation and permeabilization (ThermoFisher) and antibodies for markers listed below according to manufactures instruction. Samples were measured on a CytoFlex flow cytometer (Beckman-Coulter). Flow cytometry data were analyzed with FlowJo version 10.8.1 (BD Biosciences). Single stains and fluorescence-minus-one controls were used for gating. CD4 + T cells expressing CD154 and CD169 and CD8 + T cells expressing CD137and CD69 were defined as SARS-COV-2 reactive T cells. Unspecific activation in unstimulated controls was subtracted from stimulated samples to account for SARS-CoV-2-specific activation in the presented frequencies. Responses were considered if they are identifiable as a visible cell cluster exceeding 10 T cells and 0.01% of CD4 or CD8 T-cells, respectively.
body_text.section: Analysis of SARS-CoV-2-reactive T cells by flow cytometry

body_text.text: Flow cytometry data was analyzed using FlowJo version 10.8.1 (BD Biosciences, USA. Statistical analysis was performed using R, version 4.0.4. Binary variables are depicted as bar plots, continuous variables are depicted as box plots; the maximum length of the whiskers corresponds to 1.5 times the interquartile range. In all cases, the sub-cohorts were compared

back_matter.text: only with respect to the same virus strain. Only two-sided tests were employed. Differences for a continuous variable between the sub-cohorts were analyzed using the paired T test. Significance threshold was set at 0.05. Since this study had an exploratory nature, we did not perform an adjustment for multiple testing (Bender et al., 2001) .
